1057417792499081216.text: all communication is done over bidirectionally-authenticated onion-service-to-onion-service connections (we call them ricochet channels) so nobody ever learns your IP address or who you're talking to. there is no user registration, so no server can track your logins

1017104602720821248.text: i regret the collateral damage caused by this, but the toxicity has characterized all my research and discussions for the past week. i needed to center it in my concerns in order to head it off. it's also not just a vocal minority; it stems from the top and it goes back a ways.

1017102829075517446.text: i'll be taking a mental health break momentarily but there's one last, very important one: the idea that i cast aspersions on the (very real) subsets of the community who are just trying to do good work in earnest, by calling the community-at-large toxic.

1017099134111805440.text: whew. discussing a *publicly known* technical flaw/open question of a major project should NOT be this taxing on a person. it should NOT be big news to the community. this conversation should have been had a long time ago for a project of this size/maturity/security sensitivity

1017097756928806915.text: i personally feel this shouldn't even be necessary, but i'm doing it anyway. i think twitter/sm has the potential to be a very powerful tool for security analysis, as it provides instant access to worldwide expert knowledge, but it presents ethical issues we haven't explored yet.

1017097146158415872.text: ...and am careful not to imply authoritative weight behind any statements. i hope you'll note i very carefully phrased my OP to point out that i haven't been researching this for long, and don't have institutional backing for my analysis/conclusions so far

1017096783288205312.text: i also have several other concerns, and i've been deliberately leaving them off main because i don't feel confident i've substantiated them well enough yet. i've been engaging people offline to explore these ideas in private instead. at worst, i bring it up in mentions [...]

1017092176508047360.text: that said, one of the founders/devs did actually respond to me and allowed me to see if my concerns actually have a solution. we reached an impasse over whether a NBPoW solution exists. only then did i feel confident enough in my critique to bring it out of mentions and onto main

1017091766099546113.text: to the claim i should have chatted with community members offline before discussing online: honestly, my platform may seem large but relatively, it is not. i did not expect to get the overwhelming response that i have. i was reaching into the void for people to talk to

1017089261718396929.text: next up, as to why i don't post positive things about iota: there's not much to discuss. if it works, it works. i don't want to come across as endorsing a project if i suspect it has fundamental flaws. if you like, here's a free one: doing #tanglemath for a week is extremely fun.

1017083326648201217.text: i promise you that if an NBPoW is published, i'll make a point of sharing and discussing it here (i do not promise i won't point out any flaws i see in it, though, but again i promise to engage with refutations honestly)

1017082804419653633.text: i criticize technical projects all the time. sometimes i'm proven wrong and i try to follow up by amplifying why (and i delete any misinfo if it seems to be spreading). imo this is what healthy debate looks like. it's not what happened here.

1017082439376756736.text: i also don't see anything wrong with pointing out technical flaws in "beta" projects, especially if my honest intention was to find smart/experienced people to explore the argument with and see if it has a solution. twitter gives me quick access to very smart people for this.

1017082391716941825.text: ..to formulate responses to all of them. i hope that if you look at my engagement before this replystorm, you'll see that i was arguing in good faith. i honestly tried to respond to everything that wasn't insulting or from trolls i've already had problems with.

1017082348347842560.text: alrighty, first is this "gish gallop" thing about the asymmetry of me using my platform to criticize. i think the initial swarm of trolls harassing me disputes this idea, and the ratio of responses to my tweets also disputes it. trolls have canned answers and it takes me ages ..

1017068768990810118.text: ok all, i'm really sorry and i know i promised to respond to every genuine argument to this, but i've fallen so far behind even after staying up all night that it's simply not possible.  my new approach will be to pull out common themes and try to respond to them all at oncepic.twitter.com/ENhs6bKuNQ

1017057744338276352.text: i'm sorry to my regular followers for the walls of tweets, but this is the best platform i have for disseminating my thoughts on this. (i also honestly like the character limit; it forces me to try writing more concisely)

1017055850492555264.text: i hope this illustrates how shutting down criticism like this prevents you from getting legitimate and free technical analysis of your projects. some very bright minds have tried, and given up due to the reactions. /thread (take two)

1017055792141398016.text: none of my conclusions above are new. it took a week's worth of free time to research relevant existing work and find where technical arguments come to an impasse. a project of this size should have had these conversations a long time ago.

1017055747618861056.text: both of these combined mean cryptographic and security experts stop criticizing iota pretty quickly. the community hasn't had the advantage of experience discussing the nuances of the debate, and the technical arguments (at least in public) are in their infancy.

1017055699841552384.text: beyond the obvious "protecting their investment," two explanations i suspect are 1) any honest criticism gets met with so much toxicity that people just give up and the debate never gets explored properly, 2) it's so obfuscated and undocumented that it's hard to catch up

1017055640542502912.text: why were people so infuriated that i wanted to discuss iota in a not-perfectly-postive light? twitter is not a peer-reviewed academic venue (a standard many seem to think should apply here) and discussing the merits of technical projects seems like a perfectly good use of it

1017055439018741761.text: then, i wrote my post above, designed explicitly to pre-empt the flowchart (hence my "rules of engagement" because i'm honestly done with the toxic vicious trolls). all of my concerns are my legitimate understanding of the state of the system.

1017055299411292161.text: once you know their flowchart, you can avoid their traps and shut them down pretty quickly. i (sadly) got pretty good at this, the brigading channels i infiltrated banned people from responding to me (many were infuriated), and things got nice and quiet again.

1016745242333270016.text: 8) per 1, the iota community is toxic and i advise everyone to steer clear of it for that reason alone, including security researchers who would do responsible disclosure via private channels. /thread

1016745118039240704.text: 7) obviously iota should be allowed to solve nascent technical challenges/growing pains, but i have strong misgivings about a "beta" product being listed on live exchanges, esp with no viability plan. people are going to lose their life savings and pensions to these things.

1016745055892180992.text: thus, any startup currently trying to sell you decentralized secure auditing, ID verification etc. based on this structure is essentially a sham with no roadmap to fulfilling its promises, per 3b. this is also the problem with "local snapshots".

1016745001978646530.text: 6) blockchains have some cool non-currency usecases like secure auditing and longterm identity verificaton (eg CT). snapshots drop the ledger. it can theoretically be kept but requires powerful nodes (currently it grows at ~5GB/week) and thus induces centralization.

1016744939491942402.text: 5) some people have suggested distributing the milestone coordinator. if you have a consensus mechanism for milestones, just use that instead. delegation runs into a similar problem, eg @sarahjamielewis's notes:https://twitter.com/SarahJamieLewis/status/1016505522231508993 …

1016744881660850181.text: the coordinator currently cannot be disabled without a solution for 2/3, which is not known at this time.

1016744835473133568.text: 4) the existing solution is to use a central 100% trusted authority called the "coordinator", which issues "milestones" and "snapshots" to issue consensus and defend vs attacks on tip selection. this is called "training wheels" or "beta".

1016744779336601601.text: an alternate solution to PoRU or PoL supposedly is in the works, but i'm extremely skeptical it can exist based on the links i've been given (such as radio resource testing, which is PoL and does not propagate). this is where the argument comes to an impasse.

1016744692812218374.text: 3) the plan to address this is to replace PoW with some sort of proof-of-resource-utilization (which either doesn't scale or admits sybil attacks) or proof-of-locality (which can't be propagated through the network, by definition).

1016744593038217216.text: 2) iota has no roadmap for scaling to the level they envision. PoW is currently done by wallets, not centralized miners, and research suggests their security does not hold unless all users near-24/7 do PoW. obviously this presents a scalability issue.

1016744481394233346.text: 1) above all, the community is toxic. any honest criticism is met with coordinated brigading, which includes attempts to discredit experts' credentials, get them fired, and hack their accounts. i've been very hesitant over whether to share any of my thoughts/findings.

1016744335730192385.text: 0) first, my rules of engagement. i will automatically mute clear astroturfer/bot accounts. i will mute ad hominem attacks. i will ignore empty "do more research" and "read the whitepaper" responses. i may take time to respond but will argue in good faith.

1016744291463585793.text: i spent a week reading about the cryptocurrency iota and i'm going to present a brief summary of my conclusions here. note that this was a free-time project for me and does not represent the views of anyone i work for.

1016333400423190528.text: responsible disclosure folks: is it unethical to do live (honest) cryptanalysis on twitter?

1012739437493653504.text: pronunciation is metadata and cwtch is metadata resistant

1012719701443710976.text: too many people lately are starting to say "privacy is a lost cause." in 10 years, i want them to be saying "learning anything about internet users without their permission is a lost cause"

1012719161234124800.text: so @openpriv is setting out to provide that easy option. we want to make a new internet where the default is for no information to be released about you at all, without your explicit and informed consent

1012718424521433089.text: this is a property i believe ALL network protocols should have. privacy by default, baked in before application development even begins. there is no good reason to be tossing IP addresses and cleartext handles around if there is an easy option not to

1012717976661970945.text: even if you're using end-to-end encrypted tools, there is still some central server that sees who you're talking to and when (metadata). using cwtch means even the developers and server operators can't see who you're talking to

1012717013825974272.text: my devices all get email and other notifications from each other. right now, that means my cell tower gets my home's IP address when i'm out and about. cwtch will run on android which means cell towers will only know i'm on tor, not what devices i'm connecting to or their IPs

1012713070601351168.text: our vision goes beyond merely making yet-another secure messenger. cwtch is designed to provide a transport library to application-layer protocols. imagine if your devices could communicate with each other from a multitude of locations, without handing out their location to ISPs

1012711444478087168.text: icymi: yesterday we released a prototype of a tool i sincerely believe is going to help change the landscape of privacy-preserving messaging and infrastructurehttps://twitter.com/OpenPriv/status/1012423117266800641 …
